article:
'Thomas Michael' "'Tim'" 'Scanlon' (born 1940) is the Alford Professor of
Natural Religion, Moral Philosophy, and Civil Polity in Harvard University's
Department of Philosophy. He has been awarded a MacArthur Foundation "Genius"
Grant. He grew up in Indianapolis, Indiana; earned his Ph.D. in philosophy from
Harvard under Burton Dreben; studied for a year at Oxford University on a
Fulbright Scholarship; and taught for many years at Princeton University, where
he had been an undergraduate student.

His dissertation and some of his first papers were in mathematical logic, where
his main concern was in proof theory, but he soon made his name in ethics and
political philosophy, where he developed a version of contractualism in the line
of John Rawls, Immanuel Kant, and Jean-Jacques Rousseau. Scanlon has also
published important work on freedom of speech, equality, tolerance, foundations
of contract law, human rights, conceptions of welfare, theories of justice, as
well as on foundational questions in moral theory.

His teaching in the department has included courses on theories of justice,
equality, and recent ethical theory. His book, What We Owe to Each Other, was
published by Harvard University Press in 1998; a collection of papers on
political theory, The Difficulty of Tolerance, was published by Cambridge
University Press in 2003. Other recent publications include "Moral Theory,
Understanding and Disagreement", Philosophy & Phenomenological Research 55
(1995) pp. 343â356, and "Intention and Permissibility I," Proceedings of
the Aristotelian Society, Suppl. Vol. 74 (2000), pp. 301â317.

Scanlon is the father-in-law of philosopher and scholar of African American
studies Tommie Shelby, and was a close friend to professors G.A.Cohen and
John Rawls.
